messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: mino-style kozuka
messages.messageBody:
True on both accounts.

Gordon

On 2004.1.9, at 02:02 PM, Jim Gilbert wrote:

> Gordon,
> It'd be unusual to have that much empty nanako ground remaining
> outside the
> ends of the design on a Ko-Mino kogai. They tended to fill the linear
> space
> on kogai more than other groups. Their kozuka were composed more like
> most
> typical Ko-Kino or Ko-Goto, though. This one might have been
> remounted, but
> I can't be sure either way from the photos.
> Jim
> -------------------------
>
> Yeah, not so good pictures, but it has that Ko-Mino look. It also looks
> like a Kogai-naoshi.
>
> Gordon
>

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: mino-style kozuka
messages.msgSnippet: Gordon, It d be unusual to have that much empty nanako ground remaining outside the ends of the design on a Ko-Mino kogai.  They tended to fill the linear
messages.messageBody:
Gordon,
It'd be unusual to have that much empty nanako ground remaining outside the
ends of the design on a Ko-Mino kogai. They tended to fill the linear space
on kogai more than other groups. Their kozuka were composed more like most
typical Ko-Kino or Ko-Goto, though. This one might have been remounted, but
I can't be sure either way from the photos.
Jim
-------------------------

Yeah, not so good pictures, but it has that Ko-Mino look. It also looks
like a Kogai-naoshi.

Gordon
